question: A particle moves along the $x$ axis from $x_i$ to $x_f$. Of the following values of the initial and final coordinates, which results in the displacement with the largest magnitude?
A particle moves along the $x$ axis from $x_i$ to $x_f$. Of the following values of the initial and final coordinates, which results in a negative displacement?
Two automobiles are 150 kilometer apart and traveling toward each other. One automobile is moving at 60 km/h and the other is moving at 40 km/h mph. In how many hours will they meet?
The average speed of a moving object during a given interval of time is always:

options.A: the magnitude of its average velocity over the interval
options.B: the distance covered during the time interval divided by the time interval
options.C: one-half its speed at the end of the interval
options.D: its acceleration multiplied by the time interval
options.E: one-half its acceleration multiplied by the time interval.

question: A car travels 40 kilometer at an average speed of 80 km/h and then travels 40 kilometer at an average speed of 40 km/h. The average speed of the car for this 80-km trip is:

A car starts from Hither, goes 50 km in a straight line to Yon, immediately turns around, and returns to Hither. The time for this round trip is 2 hours. The magnitude of the average velocity of the car for this round trip is:

options.E: cannot be calculated without knowing the acceleration

question: A car starts from Hither, goes 50 km in a straight line to Yon, immediately turns around, and returns to Hither. The time for this round trip is 2 hours. The average speed of the car for this round trip is:

options.E: cannot be calculated without knowing the acceleration

question: The coordinate of a particle in meter is given by $x(t) = 16t − 3.0t^3$, where the time $t$ is in second. The particle is momentarily at rest at $t =$

A drag racing car starts from rest at $t = 0$ and moves along a straight line with velocity given by $v = bt^2$, where $b$ is a constant. The expression for the distance traveled by this car from its position at $t = 0$ is:
A ball rolls up a slope. At the end of three second its velocity is 20 cm/s; at the end of eight second its velocity is 0. What is the average acceleration from the third to the eighth second?
The coordinate of an object is given as a function of time by $x = 7t − 3t^2$, where $x$ is in meter and $t$ is in second. Its average velocity over the interval from $t = 0$ to $t = 4$ s is:
The velocity of an object is given as a function of time by $v = 4t − 3t^2$, where $v$ is in m/s and $t$ is in second. Its average velocity over the interval from t = 0 to t = 2 s:

options.E: cannot be calculated unless the initial position is given

question: The coordinate of an object is given as a function of time by $x = 4t^2 −3t^3$, where $x$ is in meter and t is in second. Its average acceleration over the interval from t = 0 to t = 2 s is:

Each of four particles move along the $x$ axis. Their coordinates (in meter) as functions of time (in second) are given by: $$ \begin{aligned} \text{particle 1:} & x(t)=3.5-2.7t^3 \\ \text{particle 2:} & x(t)=3.5+2.7t^3 \\ \text{particle 3:} & x(t)=3.5-2.7t^2 \\ \text{particle 4:} & x(t)=3.5-3.4t - 2.7t^3 \end{aligned} $$ Which of these particles have constant acceleration?

Each of four particles move along an $x$ axis. Their coordinates (in meter) as functions of time (in second) are given by $$ \begin{aligned} \text{particle 1:} & x(t)=3.5-2.7t^3 \\ \text{particle 2:} & x(t)=3.5+2.7t^3 \\ \text{particle 3:} & x(t)=3.5-2.7t^2 \\ \text{particle 4:} & x(t)=3.5-3.4t - 2.7t^3 \end{aligned} $$ Which of these particles is speeding up for t > 0?
An object starts from rest at the origin and moves along the $x$ axis with a constant acceleration of 4 m/s$^2$. Its average velocity as it goes from $x$ = 2 m to $x$ = 8 m is:
Of the following situations, which one is impossible?

options.A: A body having velocity east and acceleration east
options.B: A body having velocity east and acceleration west
options.C: A body having zero velocity and non-zero acceleration
options.D: A body having constant acceleration and variable velocity
options.E: A body having constant velocity and variable acceleration

question: Throughout a time interval, while the speed of a particle increases as it moves along the $x$ axis, its velocity and acceleration might be:
A particle moves on the $x$ axis. When its acceleration is positive and increasing:

options.E: none of the above must be true

question: A particle moves along the $x$ axis according to the equation $x = 6t^2$, where $x$ is in meter and $t$ is in second. Therefore:

options.A: the acceleration of the particle is 6 m/s$^2$
options.C: the particle follows a parabolic path
options.D: each second the velocity of the particle changes by 9.8 m/s

question: Over a short interval near time t = 0 the coordinate of an automobile in meter is given by $x(t) = 27t − 4.0t^3$, where $t$ is in second. At the end of 1.0 s the acceleration of the auto is:

Over a short interval, starting at time t = 0, the coordinate of an automobile in meter is given by $x(t) = 27t − 4.0t^3$, where t is in second. The magnitudes of the initial (at t = 0) velocity and acceleration of the auto respectively are:
At time t = 0 a car has a velocity of 16 m/s. It slows down with an acceleration given by $−0.50t$, in m/s$^2$ for t in second. It stops at t =
At time t = 0 a car has a velocity of 16 m/s. It slows down with an acceleration given by $−0.50t$, in m/s$^2$ for $t$ in second. At the end of 4.0 s it has traveled:
At time t = 0 a car has a velocity of 16 m/s. It slows down with an acceleration given by $−0.50t$, in m/s$^2$ for $t$ in second. By the time it stops it has traveled:
Starting at time t = 0, an object moves along a straight line with velocity in m/s given by $v(t) = 98 − 2t^2$, where t is in second. When it momentarily stops its acceleration is:
Starting at time t = 0, an object moves along a straight line. Its coordinate in meter is given by $x(t) = 75t − 1.0t^3$, where t is in second. When it momentarily stops its acceleration is:
A car, initially at rest, travels 20 m in 4 s along a straight line with constant acceleration. The acceleration of the car is:
A racing car traveling with constant acceleration increases its speed from 10 m/s to 50 m/s over a distance of 60 m. How long does this take?

options.E: The time cannot be calculated since the speed is not constant

question: A car starts from rest and goes down a slope with a constant acceleration of 5 m/s$^2$. After 5 s the car reaches the bottom of the hill. Its speed at the bottom of the hill, in meter per second, is:
A car moving with an initial velocity of 25 m/s north has a constant acceleration of 3 m/s$^2$ south. After 6 second its velocity will be:
An object with an initial velocity of 12 m/s west experiences a constant acceleration of 4 m/s$^2$ west for 3 second. During this time the object travels a distance of:
How far does a car travel in 6 s if its initial velocity is 2 m/s and its acceleration is 2 m/s$^2$ in the forward direction?

At a stop light, a truck traveling at 15 m/s passes a car as it starts from rest. The truck travels at constant velocity and the car accelerates at 3 m/s$^2$. How much time does the car take to catch up to the truck?
A ball is in free fall. Its acceleration is:

options.A: downward during both ascent and descent
options.B: downward during ascent and upward during descent
options.C: upward during ascent and downward during descent
options.D: upward during both ascent and descent
options.E: downward at all times except at the very top, when it is zero

question: A ball is in free fall. Upward is taken to be the positive direction. The displacement of the ball during a short time interval is:

options.A: positive during both ascent and descent
options.B: negative during both ascent and descent
options.C: negative during ascent and positive during descent
options.D: positive during ascent and negative during descent

question: An object is shot vertically upward. While it is rising:

options.A: its velocity and acceleration are both upward
options.B: its velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward
options.C: its velocity and acceleration are both downward
options.D: its velocity is downward and its acceleration is upward
options.E: its velocity and acceleration are both decreasing

question: Which one of the following statements is correct for an object released from rest?

options.A: The average velocity during the first second of time is 4.9 m/s
options.B: During each second the object falls 9.8 m
options.C: The acceleration changes by 9.8 m/s$^2$ every second
options.D: The object falls 9.8 m during the first second of time
options.E: The acceleration of the object is proportional to its weight

question: An object is thrown straight up from ground level with a speed of 50 m/s. If g = 10 m/s$^2$ its distance above ground level 1.0 s later is:
An object is thrown straight up from ground level with a speed of 50 m/s. If g = 10 m/s$^2$ its distance above ground level 6.0 s later is:
At a location where g = 9.80 m/s$^2$, an object is thrown vertically down with an initial speed of 1.00 m/s. After 5.00 s the object will have traveled:
An object is thrown vertically upward at 35 m/s. Taking g = 10 m/s$^2$, the velocity of the object 5 s later is:
A feather, initially at rest, is released in a vacuum 12 m above the surface of the earth. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The maximum velocity of the feather is 9.8 m/s
options.B: The acceleration of the feather decreases until terminal velocity is reached
options.C: The acceleration of the feather remains constant during the fall
options.D: The acceleration of the feather increases during the fall
options.E: The acceleration of the feather is zero

question: An object is released from rest. How far does it fall during the second second of its fall?
A heavy ball falls freely, starting from rest. Between the third and fourth second of time it travels a distance of:
As a rocket is accelerating vertically upward at 9.8 m/s$^2$ near Earth's surface, it releases a projectile. Immediately after release the acceleration (in m/s$^2$) of the projectile is:
A stone is released from a balloon that is descending at a constant speed of 10 m/s. Neglecting air resistance, after 20 s the speed of the stone is:
An object dropped from the window of a tall building hits the ground in 12.0 s. If its acceleration is 9.80 m/s$^2$, the height of the window above the ground is:
Neglecting the effect of air resistance a stone dropped off a 175-m high building lands on the ground in:
A stone is thrown vertically upward with an initial speed of 19.5 m/s. It will rise to a maximum height of:
A baseball is hit straight up and is caught by the catcher 2.0 s later. The maximum height of the ball during this interval is:
An object is thrown straight down with an initial speed of 4 m/s from a window which is 8 m above the ground. The time it takes the object to reach the ground is:
A stone is released from rest from the edge of a building roof 190 m above the ground. Neglecting air resistance, the speed of the stone, just before striking the ground, is:

An object is thrown vertically upward with a certain initial velocity in a world where the acceleration due to gravity is 19.6 m/s$^2$. The height to which it rises is _______ that to which the object would rise if thrown upward with the same initial velocity on the Earth. Neglect friction.

options.E: cannot be calculated from the given data

question: A projectile is shot vertically upward with a given initial velocity. It reaches a maximum height of 100 m. If, on a second shot, the initial velocity is doubled then the projectile will reach a maximum height of:

One object is thrown vertically upward with an initial velocity of 100 m/s and another object with an initial velocity of 10 m/s. The maximum height reached by the first object will be ______ that of the other.
The area under a velocity-time graph represents:
Displacement can be obtained from:

options.A: the slope of an acceleration-time graph
options.B: the slope of a velocity-time graph
options.C: the area under an acceleration-time graph
options.D: the area under a velocity-time graph
options.E: the slope of an acceleration-time graph

question: An object has a constant acceleration of 3 m/s$^2$. The position versus time graph for this object has a slope:

Which of the following five acceleration versus time graphs represents the motion of an object moving in a straight line at a constant velocity of 20 m/s?
Which of the following five position versus time graphs represents the motion of an object whose speed is increasing?

options.A: During the interval from 1.0 s to 3.0 s
options.E: At no other time less than or equal to 5 s

question: The diagram shows a velocity-time graph for a car moving in a straight line. At point P the car must be:

options.E: moving at about 45◦ with respect to the $x$ axis

question: The graph represents the straight line motion of a car. How far does the car travel between t = 2 s and t = 5 s?
